properties.title: Three Sisters Rock
properties.story: A Dreamtime story of the Three Sisters Rock (also known as Two Sisters) tells of three sisters swimming off the headland at Broken Head.

properties.title: Brays Beach and Whites Beach
properties.story: Located just south of Broken Head these picturesque cove beaches backed by forest covered cliffs were used for hunting and camping by our people.

properties.title: Tallow Creek
properties.story: Tallow Creek includes small lakes and wetlands and is located south of Cumbebin (Byron Bay) behind the dunal area along Tallow Beach and flows intermittently into the Pacific Ocean. 'This is our stomping ground as youâ€™d call it' (Aunty Linda Vidler).

properties.title: Currenba, Palm Valley
properties.story: Currenba is located at The Pass a sheltered beach popular for picnicking, surfing and boating access to the Bay and beyond. It means 'gully' and refers to the natural water channels found in this forested area. Currenba is a significant place for us.

properties.title: Cavanbah, Byron Bay
properties.story: Cavanbah, which means 'meeting place', with its sweeping beachfront and sheltered places was a favourite home base and meeting place for the Arakwal people and other Bunjalung nation tribes.
